definition[0]: accepted by or involving most people in a society
example[0]: Deaf children can often be included in mainstream education.
definition[1]: to include a child with physical or mental problems in an ordinary class
definition[2]: the most usual way of doing something or thinking about something
example[2]: Depression-era laws have kept banks out of the mainstream of financial change.
definition[3]: the people whose ideas about a subject are shared by most people and regarded as normal
example[3]: He told readers he was trying to move the newspaper out of the opposition into the mainstream.
definition[4]: relating to the most frequent or usual way of doing or thinking about something
example[4]: The company has been selling interests that it considers to be outside its mainstream businesses.
example[5]: The shop now caters for the mainstream market.
definition[5]: suitable for normal people, rather than for a particular section of society
example[6]: They made the clothes less high-fashion and more mainstream.
